e4: Although a change in policy might initially cause confusion for some investors accustomed to the biased reporting, embracing transparency and honest financial reporting is crucial for building long-term trust with all stakeholders. The potential short-term market fluctuation is outweighed by the ethical imperative of accurate disclosures.
e5: An ethical reporting policy upholds transparency, accuracy, and fairness. It presents financial information in a clear and understandable manner, avoiding any intentional manipulation or distortion of figures.  Ethical reporting considers the needs of all stakeholders, including investors, creditors, employees, and the general public, ensuring they have access to reliable information for making informed decisions.  It also complies with all relevant accounting standards and legal regulations.
e6: Yes, I would have some follow-up questions for the management team.  1) Has the company considered any communication strategies to clearly explain the change in reporting policy to investors? 2) What steps will be taken to ensure accurate and consistent application of the new unbiased reporting policy moving forward? 3) Are there any potential legal ramifications associated with changing the historical reporting practice?
